sn5.1:1.1.comm: This chapter naturally follows the previous, as it features Māra challenging various bhikkhunīs. Some of these verses are also included in the Therīgāthā, without the prose narrative. The commentarial backgrounds for the nuns are available in many sources, including Malalasekera’s Dictionary of Pali proper Names, and I will not repeat them here.

sn5.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn5.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn5.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho āḷavikā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn5.1:1.3.eng: Then the nun Āḷavikā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.1:1.3.comm: Her name means “of Āḷavī”. This exchange (lacking Āḷavikā’s first verse) is echoed in Thig 3.7, where the author is named Selā. The commentary confirms that she is the same person, Selā of Āḷavī.

sn5.1:1.4.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami vivekatthinī.
sn5.1:1.4.eng: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from almsround, she went to the Dark Forest seeking seclusion.
sn5.1:1.4.comm: Normally one goes “for the day’s meditation” (divāvihārāya), whereas here, uniquely, the text has “seeking seclusion” (vivekatthinī). In line with this, the next sentence has Māra wanting her to “fall away from seclusion”, whereas normally it is “fall away from immersion”. Seclusion also occurs in Māra’s challenge. | The Dark Forest (andhavana) was a thick grove south of Sāvatthī often visited by monks and nuns for meditation. The commentary says the name means “Blind Man’s Forest”, giving an improbable origin story. But compare Sanskrit andhakūpa, “dark well” or “blind well”, a well covered over with a lid or overgrowth; also the name of a hell.

sn5.1:1.5.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā āḷavikāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo vivekamhā cāvetukāmo yena āḷavikā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āḷavikaṃ bhikkhuniṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn5.1:1.5.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Āḷavikā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from seclusion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:

sn5.1:2.2.eng: so what will seclusion do for you?

sn5.1:3.2.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?
sn5.1:3.2.eng: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”

sn5.1:3.4.pli: “māro kho ayaṃ pāpimā mama bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo vivekamhā cāvetukāmo gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti.
sn5.1:3.4.eng: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from seclusion!”

sn5.1:3.5.pli: Atha kho āḷavikā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
sn5.1:3.5.eng: Then Āḷavikā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn5.1:4.2.eng: and I’ve personally experienced it with wisdom.

sn5.1:4.3.eng: O Wicked One, kinsman of the negligent,

sn5.1:5.1.comm: This image is often found independently, and along with other similes at MN 22:3.17 and AN 5.76:15.4. The verse as a whole in found thrice in Therīgāthā: the verses of Selā (Thig 3.7:2.1), Khemā (Thig 6.3:3.1), and Uppalavaṇṇā (Thig 11.1:11.1).

sn5.1:5.2.eng: the aggregates are their chopping block.
sn5.1:5.2.comm: Khandāsaṁ resolves to khandā esaṁ.

sn5.1:5.4.eng: is now no delight for me.”

sn5.1:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Āḷavikā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn5.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho vajirā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn5.10:1.2.eng: Then the nun Vajirā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.10:1.2.comm: Although these verses are much-quoted in Buddhist literature, Vajirā is only known from this Sutta.

sn5.10:1.3.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
sn5.10:1.3.eng: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from almsround, she went to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation,

sn5.10:1.4.pli: Andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
sn5.10:1.4.eng: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree to meditate.

sn5.10:1.5.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā vajirāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo yena vajirā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vajiraṃ bhikkhuniṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn5.10:1.5.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Vajirā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:

sn5.10:2.1.comm: The challenge is the same as the previous, with “sentient being” for “puppet”.

sn5.10:3.2.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?
sn5.10:3.2.eng: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”

sn5.10:3.4.pli: “māro kho ayaṃ pāpimā mama bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti.
sn5.10:3.4.eng: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”

sn5.10:3.5.pli: Atha kho vajirā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā, māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
sn5.10:3.5.eng: Then Vajirā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn5.10:4.1.eng: “Why do you believe there’s such a thing as a <j>‘sentient being’?

sn5.10:4.3.eng: This is just a pile of conditions,

sn5.10:4.4.eng: you won’t find a sentient being here.

sn5.10:5.3.eng: So too, when the aggregates are present

sn5.10:5.4.eng: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.
sn5.10:5.4.comm: Vajirā directly opposes the Upaniṣadic view that the Self underlying the diversity of experience is no mere convention, but the true reality masked by appearances. Compare Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.5.15 and Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.15.1, where all beings are fixed in Divinity like spokes in the hub of a wheel. The Upaniṣads say that the Self or the mind is the charioteer and the body the chariot (Katha Upaniṣad 1.3.3–9, Maitrī Upaniṣad 2.6, Paiṅgala Upaniṣad 4.1).

sn5.10:6.1.eng: But it’s only suffering that comes to be,

sn5.10:6.3.eng: Naught but suffering comes to be,

sn5.10:7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ vajirā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.10:7.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vajirā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn5.10:8.6.eng: The Linked Discourses on Nuns are completed.

sn5.2:1.2.eng: Then the nun Somā robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.2:1.2.comm: For Pasenadi’s wife of the same name, see MN 90:3.1 and note.

sn5.2:1.3.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
sn5.2:1.3.eng: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from almsround, she went to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation,

sn5.2:1.4.eng: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree to meditate.

sn5.2:1.5.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā somāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo yena somā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā somaṃ bhikkhuniṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn5.2:1.5.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Somā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:

sn5.2:2.2.eng: it’s for the sages to attain.

sn5.2:2.3.comm: “Two-inch wisdom” (dvaṅgulapaññā) is literally “two finger(-breadth’s) wisdom”. It is explained by the commentary as limited wisdom; or because women hold thread between two fingers. The subcommentary and the commentary to the Therīgāthā say it is because women test whether rice is cooked by pressing a grain between two fingers. Normally, aṅgula with a number is a unit of length equal to the width of the middle finger. For example, the time past noon is measured when the sun’s shadow moves two inches (Kd 22:1.10.16), which is the same distance the shadow moves each month (Arthaśāstra 2.20.42). Thus the first commentarial explanation is the most plausible: “two-inch wisdom” means “limited wisdom”.

sn5.2:2.4.eng: it’s not possible for a woman.”
sn5.2:2.4.comm: It is Māra, not the Buddha, who doubts women’s capacity. It is interesting to see who adopts Māra’s view. In Mahāvastu 3.391, a brahmin ascetic urges a female competitor to throw a debating match with him, lest people say that he was beaten by “a mere woman’s two-inch wisdom”. In Vv 18:8.4, a former serving woman celebrates how she as a woman attained the Dhamma, but the commentary says this was “despite her two-inch thick intelligence”. In the late literary text Bṛhatkathāślokasaṁgraha the idiom is employed by a woman to dismiss women’s wit (22.35)—as so often, a woman makes the best misogynist—or by a man who muses that perhaps men like him are the real fools since they allow women to entice them (22.302–3).

sn5.2:3.2.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?
sn5.2:3.2.eng: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”

sn5.2:3.5.pli: Atha kho somā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
sn5.2:3.5.eng: Then Somā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn5.2:4.4.eng: as you rightly discern the Dhamma.
sn5.2:4.4.comm: Gender categories apply in a limited sense to the realm of bodily conduct, but are entirely irrelevant when it comes to meditative immersion and wisdom.

sn5.2:5.1.comm: Somā’s verses at Thig 3.8 lack this verse.

sn5.2:5.3.comm: Read asmīti. Somā rejects not just the limited categories of binary gender, but any form of self-identification.

sn5.2:5.4.eng: is fit for Māra to address.”

sn5.4:5.3.eng: I’m horrified and repelled by it,

sn5.4:6.1.eng: There are beings in the realm of luminous form,
sn5.4:6.1.comm: In this verse she declares that, not only has she transcended attachment to the senses, she has even surmounted attachment to meditative absorption.

sn5.4:6.2.eng: and others stuck in the formless.

sn5.5:1.2.eng: Then the nun Uppalavaṇṇā robed up in the morning …
sn5.5:1.2.comm: Regarded as the greatest in psychic power (AN 1.237:1.1), and, with Khemā, the ideal nun (AN 2.131:1.2, AN 4.176:2.2). She taught other nuns (Thig 13.5:27.3), and was devoted to the Buddha (Bu NP 5:1.1.1).

sn5.5:1.3.eng: and stood at the root of a sal tree in full flower.

sn5.5:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā uppalavaṇṇāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo yena uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā uppalavaṇṇaṃ bhikkhuniṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn5.5:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Uppalavaṇṇā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:

sn5.5:2.1.eng: “You’ve come to this sal tree all crowned with flowers,
sn5.5:2.1.comm: These verses are included in Uppalavaṇṇā’s at Thig 11.1:7.1, with some differences.

sn5.5:2.2.eng: and stand at its root all alone, O nun.

sn5.5:2.3.eng: Your beauty is second to none—
sn5.5:2.3.comm: Literally, “There is no-one to whom you are second in the element of beauty” (na catthi te dutiyā vaṇṇadhātu,). Thig 11.1:7.3 reads Na cāpi te dutiyo atthi koci, “There is no male companion with you”. The two lines use dutiya (“second”) in different senses, as the ordinal number, and as “companion”. The Therīgāthā commentary offers two explanations, the second of which appears to lean on a version of the line similar to that found here. This, together with the fact that the unusual term vaṇṇadhātu seems like a direct reference to her name, suggests that this version may be the original one.

sn5.5:2.4.eng: silly girl, aren’t you afraid of rascals?”

sn5.5:3.2.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?

sn5.5:3.5.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
sn5.5:3.5.eng: Then Uppalavaṇṇā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn5.5:4.3.eng: I’d stir not a hair nor panic.

sn5.5:4.4.eng: I’m not scared of you, Māra, even alone.

sn5.5:5.3.eng: I could stand between your eyebrows

sn5.5:5.4.eng: and you still wouldn’t see me.

sn5.5:6.1.eng: I’m the master of my own mind,

sn5.5:6.2.eng: I’ve developed the bases of psychic power well.

sn5.5:6.4.eng: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!”
sn5.5:6.4.comm: Despite her dauntless rejection of Māra here, a story in the Vinaya says she was once raped by a Vedic student who was infatuated with her (Bu Pj 1:10.5.1). The Buddha declared that one who does not consent is innocent. It seems hard to reconcile the two events, unless the Vinaya incident was when she was young and not yet accomplished. If that were the case, perhaps Māra is deliberately capitalizing on the past assault, assuming she will be traumatized by it.

sn5.5:7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.5:7.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Uppalavaṇṇā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn5.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho cālā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā …pe…
sn5.6:1.2.eng: Then the nun Cālā robed up in the morning …
sn5.6:1.2.comm: The eldest of three sisters whose verses are recorded respectively: Cālā at SN 5.6 and Thig 7.2; Upacālā at SN 5.7 and Thig 7.3; Sīsupacālā at SN 5.8 and Thig 8.1. There is considerable confusion, as verses ascribed to one sister in SN are attributed to another in the Therīgāthā. The three sisters were taught meditation by Revata (Thag 1.42).

sn5.6:1.3.eng: and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

sn5.6:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena cālā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā cālaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavoca:
sn5.6:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to Cālā and said to her,

sn5.6:2.2.eng: When you’re born, you get to enjoy sensual pleasures.

sn5.6:2.3.eng: Who put this idea in your head:

sn5.6:3.1.eng: “Death comes to those who are born,

sn5.6:3.2.eng: when you’re born you undergo sufferings—

sn5.6:3.4.eng: that’s why you shouldn’t approve of rebirth.

sn5.6:4.1.eng: The Buddha taught me the Dhamma

sn5.6:4.4.eng: he settled me in the truth.

sn5.6:5.1.eng: There are beings in the realm of luminous form,

sn5.6:5.2.eng: and others stuck in the formless.

sn5.6:6.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ cālā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.6:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Cālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn5.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho upacālā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā …pe…
sn5.7:1.2.eng: Then the nun Upacālā robed up in the morning …
sn5.7:1.2.comm: The younger sister of Cālā, her verses are at Thig 7.3.

sn5.7:1.3.eng: and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

sn5.7:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena upacālā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā upacālaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavoca:
sn5.7:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to Upacālā and said to her,

sn5.7:1.5.eng: “Nun, where do you want to be reborn?”

sn5.7:1.6.eng: “I don’t want to be reborn anywhere, sir.”

sn5.7:2.1.eng: “There are the gods of the thirty-three, <j>and those of Yama;
sn5.7:2.1.comm: Māra mentions five of the sense-sphere heavens, omitting only the lowest of them, the realm of the Four Great Kings.

sn5.7:2.3.eng: the gods who love to create,

sn5.7:2.4.eng: and the gods who control that imagined by others.

sn5.7:2.5.eng: Set your heart on such places,

sn5.7:3.1.eng: “The gods of the thirty-three, <j>and those of Yama;
sn5.7:3.1.comm: These verses are attributed to Sīsūpacālā at Thig 8.1:5.1.

sn5.7:3.3.eng: the gods who love to create,

sn5.7:3.4.eng: and the gods who control that imagined by others—

sn5.7:3.5.eng: they’re bound with the bonds of sensuality;

sn5.7:3.6.eng: they fall under your sway again.

sn5.7:4.1.eng: All the world is on fire,

sn5.7:5.4.eng: and not frequented by ordinary people.”

sn5.7:6.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ upacālā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.7:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Upacālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
